div.p: Greetings. I, my father, am suffering greatly; I feel incredible torments.

It is colic pain; if greater inflammation occurs, it is over for me. I have served Christ, in whose presence I will soon appear to give an account of my duty. Concerning the bishop, there is nothing to fear; the greed of the evangelicals is so great that all their treacherous efforts must be countered. Everyone seeks their own.
If God were to call me from this troubled life, do not be the author to send another from ZÃ¼rich; for to all the difficulties that my function has had, the ingratitude of these people is immense.
You too take some care of my children, which I beg you by the immortal God; for I have not sought my own, but rather expended myself, so as not to give offense. I write this with a trembling hand.
I pray to God to keep you safe for His church. Amen. Johannes Fabricius, your most observant.

In one God my hope is firmly fixed, to whom I commend myself and all mine; but in the meantime, care is not lacking. We have a very skilled doctor; he counters obstructions and inflammations with enemas and says there is still some hope. But whatever it is, I am prepared, wherever God may call me.
I do not want anything to be said yet to my father-in-law; if the illness worsens, tomorrow I will arrange everything concerning my wife and children.
To the most illustrious man, excellent in learning and piety, Heinrich Bullinger, my esteemed father.
